docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is, according to Ecclesiastes, ''a time to be born and a time to die, a time to plant and a time to pull up that which is planted, a time to kill and a time to heal, a time to break down and a time to build up.'' The biblical list goes on and on as if the ancients had anticipated discoveries made only in the last decade about the many different times in life. For, it turns out, there is also (among many others) a time to eat and a time to fast, a time to work and a time to play, a time to sleep and a time to wake up and even a time to treat and a time to withhold treatment, and these times often conflict with the schedules imposed upon us by the practical world. While some people clearly live by the clock on the wall, all of us are governed by a complex series of inner clocks that regulate hundreds of biological functions. Our inner clocks in part dictate our times of elation and depression, patience and irritability, precision and carelessness.
